The employees were not very friendly but I guess what can you expect out of 16 year old teenagers. I ordered a chicken plate and it was greasy and gross. The spaghetti side was sugary and disgusting.
The place was dirty too but I will say that it was also packed with people. Tustin, CA 5/18/2012 3 Check-ins Here Delish! But chaotic!!!
Jollibee is the number one food chain in the Philippines. Anaheim is one of their many branches worldwide. Great variety from burgers to fried chicken to rice to spaghetti, satisfying most cravings.
If you're not familiar with the menu and the food would recommend trying the chicken first. Spaghetti is sweeter than the usual Italian offerings. Personally I love the burger steak (hamburger patty with mushroom gravy), you can also order a fried egg and have it loco moco style. Lumpia (eggrolls) are available.
The drink coolers are delish--ube (purple taro) and buko pandan (coconut and screwpine) are very yummy.
The little pies also have some different flavors peach mango and banana lanka (lanka is jackfruit) a departure from your apple and cherry pies.
Remember when you're eating here it is fast food, so don't expect too much, but enjoy the experience and tastes of another culture--Americanized. It's also a quick way to enjoy what has been rated as one of the best fast-food chains in the world by international online travel magazine Travel+Leisure.

La Palma, CA 3/14/2012 If you do not like Jollibee chicken and spaghetti before coming here, please check your Americanized taste buds at the door.
Don't get me wrong, I'm an OC-born-and-raised chic but this IS modern day Filipino fast food so get over it people! :D Jollibee is NOT meant to be authentic filipino food or traditional Filipino take-out. It, truly, is the nation's version of McDonald's.
The chicken is meant to be crispy, warm, a bit salty with a seemingly bland gravy to balance it out. And OH MY GOD! YES!! As every Pinoy/Pinay knows, the spaghetti is as sweet-and mixed with little chopped hot dogs-as it should be. The peach mango pies are still so flaky, hot and full of sweet goodness it almost made me close my eyes and smile.
You're treated with real Filipino hospitality from the moment you open the door or order from drive-thru.
If you're fien'n' for something that will take you "home," dine in. It won't be as crowded in the morning but you'll still forget you're in the States for a while :)

Santa Ana, CA 1/26/2012 4 photos A smiling Jollibee himself greets all who enter. This bee has no stinger in it's butt and resembles Bob's Big Boy. Inside, it's fairly roomy with red furniture in a bright modern interior. The same smile greeted me at the counter and those who go through the drive through service. It's a favorite hangout for many of the mostly Filipino American families that were here. Besides the many locations in the Philippines, there are several locations in California, e.g. Union City, Cerritos, etc
As a 20-year organic gardener, I have plenty of reasons to love bees. They make my pollinating plants jolly. But Jollibee food-- well, it's just okay. The friend I went with said his hamburger was mediocre. No comment from me since I didn't try it. After having great fried chicken like Jim Dandy's in LA and Honey's Kettle in Culver City, this chicken just doesn't compare. I was more than happy patronizing a restaurant whose investors, managers, and workers are from my homeland. But my taste buds were not so happy. Those who like Jollibees would probably approve my 2nd grade Catholic school nuns in the PI slapping my keyboarding hands.
The staff was smiling and friendly. I saw several people eating their pancit (noodles) and fish. I had their two piece Fried Chicken special with rice and gravy. The chicken was tender, but too greasy and not very. I needed napkins under each piece to drain off excess fat. The chicken must've been either pressure cooked like KFC or their oil is not that hot. Overall, not bad, not great. Church's and Popeye's chicken -definitely crisper, less greasy, and better seasoned - are better.
In the Philippines where I went for a vacation last year, this chain with their spaghetti with hot dog slices excessive sugar is hugely popular. But, it's just too sweet to me though lots of people like it. Definitely very Filipino (sugar as a preservative, hot dogs or Vienna sausage as a meat) in it's approach.
I didn't have it this time, but I like their halo-halo which I didn't have here. I have had at their Cerritos location. BTW, halo halo which translates to mix-mix is a shaved ice and sugar, evaporated milk, and preserved Filipino fruits dessert that is sometimes topped with Ube (taro) or other ice cream. You mix it up and spoon into your mouth. Other than that, with this being a very crowded mini mall especially during rush hour, I'm not going to rush back here. But if a Filipino person gets homesick, this place will probably help him or her feel connected with the motherland.

Buena Park, CA 3/17/2012 1 Check-in Here Ah, its time to review the Mickey D's of Philippines.
DO NOT COMPARE THIS PLACE TO KFC OR ROSCOES!
People usually come here for their fried chicken, halohalo and the Pinoy spaghetti an d the fried pies! With that said, lets break them downnnn!!!
Fried chicken: Do not compare KFC or Roscoes. They serve you dark meat, which is not very popular in US but!, there is usually more flavor on the dark meat then the white meat! ba bam!
Halohalo: If your American or "white", you won't notice the difference between a good halohalo and the halohalo they sell here. Its alright, but really, I feel a little ripoff everytime I get it here. It is just great for a hot summer day.
Spaghetti: What is the difference between the spaghetti you know and this type of spaghetti?? - Pinoy spaghetti is usually sweet but it can be too sweet for your tastebuds so it really depends on the people.
Pies! - Remember those fruit pies you buy from Walmart?? Well...same thing but fried and warm in the inside.
This place is FIlipino fast food so if this is your first time here, you will feel like an alien. It is also for nostalgic purposes and it is not the flagship of Filipino food. === Pros: Fried chicken The piess!! Pinoy hospitality and ... THE MASCOT IS A BEE!!!
Cons: It really depends on the person if they like it.
DO NOT COMPARE THIS PLACE TO KFC OR ROSCOES!

But alas, here we are in California. And in California, we live by California's standards. And the standard for a good fast-food burger is In-N-Out, the standard for good fast-food fried chicken is Popeyes, and the standard for good fast-food spaghetti is----in a jar of Ragu? It's all actually pretty good&it makes me wonder if Jollibee can compete.
Don't get me wrong, I love Jollibee. I love what it stands for. I love the idea, I admire its recent success to be able to open up a branch in Anaheim. I wouldn't change it...but I'd rather just give it the occasional visit when I'm in Cebu, Philippines where I'd appreciate it more. Westminster, CA 10/3/2011 1 photo Awww man.... I wish I was the first to review, especially if the first review was only one sentence long and seems like they didn't step foot in the place. No biggie though; they'll probably edit it once they tried the place.
So here goes... I've heard a lot about Jollibee from my Filipino friends and the comments made on http://OCRegister.com , so I wanted to go and check it out.
My friend and I ordered the same thing but with different sides. We both got the C2 Chicken Joy meal that comes with 2 pieces of chicken (original or spicy), 2 sides of your choice, and a drink. For sides, she got sweet potato fries and mashed potatoes, while I got french fries and buttered corn.
First off, the chicken was nicely cooked (crunchy skin on the outside - my fave part. hahaha) and juicy meat on the inside. The size of the chicken pieces were also big compared to KFC.
The sides we had: - Sweet potato fries are the bomb! The way they are criss-cut makes it fun to eat and the pattern gives it more surface area to actually fry and become crunchy. - Regular fries were also crunchy. They were also pretty long pieces in there that weren't over-fried and oily. Just the right amount of frying. - Buttered corn: Tastes like regular buttered corn. - Mashed potatoes: Good thing they gave us one small carton of gravy with each meal because you're going to need the extra gravy on the mashed potatoes. I really wish there was more flavoring in the actual potatoes as well.
The service was nice. When we came (around 1:30pm), it was so crowded, we had to wait outside in a line before getting inside. The cashier was a bit forgetful. I had to repeat my order three times before he was able to input it correctly. Even then, our order was still wrong, but that was easily fixed (I got the spicy, while my cousin got the original when it was suppose to be the other way around). The whole experience was tolerable though because the place did just open.
The atmosphere was great. Very clean since it just opened, but the only thing I would complain about would be how freezing it is in the main lobby!!! Good thing there was a pocket room on the inside where it was much warmer. The place was also connected to the Red Ribbon Bakery on the side.
I would love to come here again if I'm ever in the area, but that's about it. If I ever do come back though, I'll try a burger that time around since I have also heard many great things about that.
